lines.text: Slash. Dash. Crash. Mash. Bash. Relax, girls. Relax! Don't attack your machines. Remember the typewriter's an instrument, not a man.
Peter, Paula's pretty pet pekingese puppy playfully pulled poor pussy's paw.
It's always Spring with my little darlings. They only know one season and that's the mating season.
What's this? Are you typing in code?
Oh, eh, the keys got mixed up.
Looks like a Chinese laundry ticket.
You can't spell. You can't take dictation and you can't type. As a business woman you're a complete failure.
You mean to tell me you're giving a second thought to what that little nitwit said? What have we got to worry about? We have this school, we're free. Independent!
We certainly are. That's just the trouble.
Now don't tell me you're getting Spring fever too?
I sometimes find a lack of experience an asset in a woman. That is, in a woman secretary. Yes, I've always said, "As the twig is bent, so is the tree inclined".
Oh, wait. Wait!
Let nature take its course, deary.
Oh, she can't even spell.
She can spell what he wants in capital letters.
He's fired another one of our girls. He's fired half his office force. He wants to know what's wrong with the modern woman.
The modern man.
I'm going down there and talk to him. I just want to know what he expects from a secretary.
I'm Miss Baldwin from the Supreme Secretarial School and I...
Oh, you are, huh. Mmm. Well, offhand I can't tell a thing about you. I will say though, there's some suggestion of modesty. The other girls trooped in here looking like a lot of chorus girls!
You've got the school, a business of your own, and you want to give that up for a twenty-five dollar a week job?
But, Helen, you don't understand. He's young. He's very good looking. He's healthy. He's intelligent. And he's not married!
Oh, you want some raw carrot?
Eh, no thank you.
Good for you. Builds brain cells.
Oh really, you know I always thought that fish...
Fish? Fish! Popular fallacy.
[Back to dictating his letter]
What did I say last?
Poppycock.

For ages, the heart has been elevated to a place of primary importance in the human body. Poets as well as scientists have helped contribute to this elevation. By now, the fallacy is an excepted thing. But, I wish to explode this myth. The heart is not the seat of our emotions! That place of honor belongs to the liver!
Oh, have I shown you an article on body tone and office efficiency in the May issue?
I wait for years, finally, I pick my man. And what is he? A slave driver. A calisthenics expert. A guy that lives on mattress stuffing!
You see that? It's meat. Ah, but, it's bad for you. You lose your teeth, your eyesight, your brain cells. It's slow death. Steak! Mmm, come kill Mama.
He looks into your eyes to find out the condition of your liver. There's nothing human about him. He's a total loss. And that's what I picked.
Oh, what a pity. What a pity. He looks so nice. And when he smiles. He smiled twice today. I tell you, it warms you right down to your toes.
[sighs]
Where are you going?
To get you a big dose of sulfur and molasses.
Oh, you mean, make sort of a racket out of it, I suppose.

Sure. Why not? Everybody else does it. You buy toothpaste because a couple of blackface comics make you laugh. Coffee isn't coffee anymore, it's an amateur hour. Soap? Why soap is the road to love! Ballyhoo, that's what gets 'em.

Now, take your covers. Who wants to look at a man with great bulging muscles? Everybody likes to look at a beautiful woman. Put her in one of those bathing suits you could thread a needle with and everybody will stop and look. The women will try to figure how they can wear themselves down to the size...
Hey, Just, just, just a minute. Just a minute, Miss Baldwin. I'm not putting out a sex magazine. Body and Brain is a dignified publication.
But, it doesn't have to be dull!
Its beginning to rain!
That's fine, I love rain.
So do I, on the roof.
Oh, you're spoiled and soft!
I"m cold and wet!

This is a health magazine, Miss Baldwin. Health! Not a circus! You were brought in here as a secretary, not an advisor. And just because I was foolish enough to ask your opinion about the magazine, you took advantage of it. You and like all the other women in business, you can't keep your place!
It serves you right for ever letting on you're smarter than a man. They can't take it.
Don't be so bellicose. Men don't like women who are bellicose. I don't wanna have no trouble from you.
You know, you really ought to smile all the time.
What's happened to the chief?
I don't know. Why, what's the matter?
Oh, keep your blouse on, he's alright.

I think education is terribly important. I came pretty near getting a dose of it myself. My father was awfully ambitious on account of me. I can hear him like it was only yesterday saying to Mama, "Mama, we ought to do something about Maizie's mind." Oh, yeah, of course he never did, on account being took very sudden and leaving me to look after poor Mama. But, even if I couldn't take a course, I was always lapping up culture.
Oh, Maizie, perhaps Mr. Gilbert would like a high ball.
Would you?
Oh, thanks. I don't think I will.
Oh, that's wonderful. I wish more men were like that. People laugh at me for being so temperance. But, it sure burns me up to see men guzzling a lot of hooch!
I think the body is awfully important, don't you Mr. Gilbert?
Oh, eh, terribly important.

My mother was of the same opinion. I can hear her say now, "Take care of your body, Maizie because its all you've got". Of course, it hasn't been very easy, on account of my not bein' strong. I often think my body's my own worst enemy.
Excuse it, please, Mr. Houston. Mr. Gilbert and me was discussing our bodies.
Are you going to dictate?
Is, eh, is she a woman?
Oh, yes.
Oh dear, I do hope she'll like me. Women don't always do.
Miss Baldwin, are there two "b"s in a liver?
What a worm. What a worm!
No, Ernest, I'm the worm!
Good morning, darling. What's the matter with my toots?
Don't call me toots!
Why not?
In the office I'd like you to remember its Mr. Gilbert.
Anything you say, toots!

You are so satisfied with yourself and you keep on making one mistake right after the other. First, you act like a fussy old maid. Next, you're sillier than a college boy out on a spree. You haven't any sense at all!
